SUMMARY: E. coli multidrug resistance regulator [1409590, 7730261] EmrR, negatively regulates transcription of genes that code for multidrug resistance pumps that extrude structurally unrelated antimicrobial agents from cell [7730261, 11321589] and possibly it also represses a gene that codes for a porin [11321589]. When EmrR is overexpressed ( emrR gene in multicopy), it is able to repress marRAB operon, which encodes two transcriptional regulators [8521301]. EmrR, which is also known as MprA, microcin production regulation, locus A [2152912] has also been shown to be a repressor of plasmid-encoded genes involved in microcin biosynsis [2152912, 1840583, 9484896]. Microcins are low-molecular-weight polypeptide antibiotics [4071]. EmrR dimer binds 2,4-dinitrophenol, carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP), and carbonyl cyanide p-(trifluoro-methoxy)phenylhydrazone, predicted ligands of EmrAB pump, with high affinity [10438794]. Binding of se agents interferes with ability of EmrR to bind DNA [10991887]. This dimeric protein [10438794]recognizes and binds an imperfect inverted repeat DNA sequence [10991887]. EmrR belongs to MarR family of transcriptional regulators [8521301] which respond to a variety of phenolic compounds and are found in gram-positive and gram-negative species as well as in mycobacteria [8521301]. proteins of this family have a helix-turn-helix DNA-binding motif at center [9141683] while ligand-binding domain is possibly located at N-terminal domain [10438794]. EmrR shows 28% and 47% identity and similarity, respectively, to MarR protein [8521301]. Overproduction of EmrR from a multicopy plasmid causes a mutator phenotype that includes an increase in frameshift and base substitution mutations [15225322]. emrR is first gene of emrRAB operon whose transcription is induced by antimicrobial agents such as salicylic acid, CCCP, and nalidixic acid, among ors; induction requires repressor of operon EmrR [7730261]. Expression of emrR is not osmoregulated [1840583]. Reviews: [11321580, 12456787, 8866468].
